content: The Act may be cited as the "Worker Ownership, Readiness and Knowledge Act" or the "WORK Act". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act, also known as the "Worker Ownership, Readiness and Knowledge Act" or the "WORK Act", defines key terms such as Director, Existing program, New program, Office, and Secretary. The Act, known as the "WORK Act," defines key terms such as Director, Existing program, New program, Office, Secretary (referring to the Secretary of Labor), and State (referring to any of the 50 States within the United States of America). The "WORK Act" defines key terms and establishes the Office of Employee Ownership and Participation. The "WORK Act" establishes the Office of Employee Ownership and Participation within the Department of Labor. The Director appointed by the Secretary will support and facilitate programs promoting employee ownership and participation in business decision-making at the state level. Federal grants may be provided to support these programs. The Office of Employee Ownership and Participation, established by the "WORK Act," supports state programs promoting employee ownership and participation in business decision-making. It facilitates the formation of new programs by providing Federal grants, acting as a clearinghouse for program techniques, and funding projects for information gathering and dissemination. Additionally, it holds or funds an annual conference for representatives from States with existing programs, developing new programs, and without existing programs. Additionally, it holds or funds an annual conference for representatives from States with existing programs, developing new programs, and without existing programs. SEC. 4. PROGRAMS REGARDING EMPLOYEE OWNERSHIP AND PARTICIPATION. The Secretary will establish a program to promote employee ownership and participation in business decision-making within the States, focusing on education and outreach about the benefits of employee ownership and financial education. The program aims to promote employee ownership and participation in business decision-making by providing tools for sharing ideas, technical assistance for transitioning ownership to employees, training on employee participation methods, and assisting entities in applying for funding and establishing new programs. The program established by the Secretary includes provisions targeting key groups for activities such as workshops, conferences, and distributing materials on employee ownership and succession planning. Preliminary technical assistance is provided for employee groups, managers, and retiring owners. The program established by the Secretary includes provisions for employee groups, managers, and retiring owners to explore employee ownership. It assists in feasibility assessments, funding third-party studies, and provides a data bank for legal and financial advice. Additionally, it offers courses on employee participation and fosters networks of employee-owned companies. The program established by the Secretary promotes employee ownership and participation in businesses through training, visits to existing programs, and providing materials for training. Regulations require programs to encourage actions that increase productivity and broaden capital ownership. The Director may make grants for new and existing programs within a State for education, outreach, technical assistance, training activities, cooperation among employee-owned firms, and training for participants in existing programs. The grants for training shall not exceed 10 percent of the total amount of grants made under this Act. The Director determines grant amounts and conditions under this Act, with applications required from entities seeking grants. States can submit applications on behalf of local entities, and if a State fails to establish a program, entities can apply directly. The Director determines grant amounts and conditions under this Act. States failing to establish a program can allow local entities to apply for grants directly in subsequent fiscal years. Recipients of grants have limitations on the amount they can receive each fiscal year. For fiscal years 2011 to 2014, grant amounts were $330,000, $363,000, $399,300, and $439,200 respectively. Recipients must submit annual reports detailing grant expenditures. SEC. 6. OFFICE REPORTING. The Director must submit a report to Congress within 36 months of this Act's enactment, detailing progress on employee ownership in US businesses and analyzing costs and benefits. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS: For grants under section 5, the following amounts are authorized to be appropriated: $3,500,000 for 2010, $5,500,000 for 2011, $8,000,000 for 2012, $10,500,000 for 2013, and $13,500,000 for 2014. Administrative expenses for the Office are capped at $350,000 or 5.0% of the maximum amount available under subsection (a) for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014.
